page.title: 18CHANGES IN CHALFONT ST GILES
page.content: The village pond,fed by the River Mis- bourne,was once much larger, covering most of what is now the green and the road,then a narrow lane.Old pictures show an ancient elm standing near the junction of Bowstridge Lane and which, in spite of a petition from villagers, was felled to allow road widening.Also gone are the stocks,last occupied by a Mr.Lofty for stealing a chicken.The old Pheasant still stands,much altered from its original stone to a mock Tudor,at the point where the new main through road from Chalfont St Peter to Amersham skirts the village.In days gone by the pub had bow windows so that refreshment could be passed out to men holding their horses.Here is a recent change-a mini-roundabout system guiding the busy modern traffic through the once peace- ful,narrow laned crossing of a century ago.
